[SEC] 1. Introduction.[SUBSEC] 1.1 Purpose: The Flea Market System (FMS) defines secure transactions, administrative controls, API interactions, and data integrity enforcement.
[SEC] 1. Introduction.[SUBSEC] 1.2 Scope: FMS supports authentication, encrypted storage, transaction logging, API interactions, and administrative control.

[SUBSEC] 1.3 Product Perspective.[SUBSUBSEC] 1.3.1 System Interfaces: FMS integrates with web servers, databases, and APIs for authentication and payments.
[SUBSEC] 1.3 Product Perspective.[SUBSUBSEC] 1.3.2 User Interfaces: FMS provides a web UI for buyers, sellers, and administrators.
[SUBSEC] 1.3 Product Perspective.[SUBSUBSEC] 1.3.3 Hardware Interfaces: FMS runs on cloud-hosted infrastructure, supporting desktops and mobile devices.
[SUBSEC] 1.3 Product Perspective.[SUBSUBSEC] 1.3.4 Software Interfaces: FMS uses React.js frontend, Node.js backend, and PostgreSQL for data storage.
[SUBSEC] 1.3 Product Perspective.[SUBSUBSEC] 1.3.5 Communications Interfa: FMS ensures encrypted data transfer via SSL.
[SUBSEC] 1.3 Product Perspective.[SUBSUBSEC] 1.3.6 Memory Constraints: FMS optimizes concurrent transactions without performance loss.
[SUBSEC] 1.3 Product Perspective.[SUBSUBSEC] 1.3.7 Operations: FMS manages authentication, transactions, logging, and system monitoring.
[SUBSEC] 1.3 Product Perspective.[SUBSUBSEC] 1.3.8 Site Adaptation Requir: FMS ensures cross-platform access and remote security enforcement.
[SUBSEC] 1.3 Product Perspective.[SUBSUBSEC] 1.3.9 Interfaces with Servic: FMS connects to authentication, payments, and data storage APIs.

[SEC] 1. Introduction.[SUBSEC] 1.4 Product Functions: FMS enables secure authentication, transactions, logging, administrative control, and compliance reporting.
[SEC] 1. Introduction.[SUBSEC] 1.5 User Characteristics: FMS is for buyers, sellers, and administrators, ensuring secure transactions.
[SEC] 1. Introduction.[SUBSEC] 1.6 Limitations: FMS requires SSL configuration for secure transmission.
[SEC] 1. Introduction.[SUBSEC] 1.7 Assumptions and Dependencie: FMS relies on encrypted authentication, secure APIs, and database integrity.
[SUBSEC] 1.8 Definitions: Transaction Logging: Tracks user activity and IP addresses for security.
Encrypted Passwords: Securely stored credentials in the database.

[SUBSEC] 2.1 External Interfaces.REQ-INTF-001: The system shall support user registration, login, and password recovery.
[SUBSEC] 2.1 External Interfaces.REQ-INTF-002: The system shall enforce secure API-based interactions for authentication and transactions.

[SUBSEC] 2.2 Functions.REQ-FUNC-001: The system shall require valid user credentials for all transactions (REQ-INTF-001).
[SUBSEC] 2.2 Functions.REQ-FUNC-002: The system shall provide an administrative interface to manage user roles, system functions, and logs (REQ-INTF-001).
[SUBSEC] 2.2 Functions.REQ-FUNC-003: The system shall ensure encrypted transaction processing and storage (REQ-INTF-002).

[SUBSEC] 2.3 Usability Requirements.REQ-USAB-001: The system shall provide an intuitive UI for buyers, sellers, and administrators, ensuring accessibility and ease of use.

[SUBSEC] 2.4 Performance Requirements.REQ-PERF-001: The system shall process transactions within 3 seconds under normal load conditions.

[SUBSEC] 2.5 Logical Database Requiremen.REQ-DB-001: The system shall securely store authentication credentials, transaction logs, and administrative activity records.

[SUBSEC] 2.6 Design Constraints.REQ-DSGN-001: The system shall utilize API-based communication between the web application and the database to ensure secure interactions.

[SUBSEC] 2.7 Standards Compliance.REQ-COMP-001: The system shall enforce encrypted authentication, secure transactions, and compliance with industry security protocols.

[SUBSEC] 2.8 Software System Attributes.REQ-ATTR-001: The system shall ensure data integrity, enforce access controls, and support secure authentication mechanisms.

[SEC] 3. Verification: Authentication, transaction security, logging, and administrative controls validated through system testing and security audits.
[SEC] 4. Supporting Information: User manuals, API documentation, encryption policies, and system security guidelines.
[SEC] 5. References: Data encryption standards, API security protocols, and best practices for secure online transactions.
